title: 10: Hygiene in the shed? Let the cows tell you! Scoring system

tasks.task: Scoring system for shed hygiene in dairy cows.
subtasks: Identifying clean cows (score 0).
Identifying slightly dirty cows (score 1) with palm-sized dirtiness.
Identifying very dirty cows (score 2) with forearm-length dirtiness.

tasks.task: Diagnosing shed hygiene issues based on dirt scores.
subtasks: Assessing cleaning of passageways or drainage issues (lower hind legs dirty, score 1).
Checking lying area hygiene (udders and lower parts dirty, score 2).
Investigating tail and flank dirt (possible diarrhea or diet-related issue, score 2).
Evaluating overall dirtiness (all over, score 2) to check for overcrowding or manure removal issues.

tasks.task: Understanding mastitis infection process in dairy cows.
subtasks: Recognizing mastitis as an udder infection.
Identifying bacteria entry via teat canal.
Acknowledging the udder's immune response to infection.
Noting that dirty udders (high hygiene score) correlate with higher risk of mastitis.

tasks.task: Observing dairy cow behavior (cows mentioning tail swishing).
subtasks: Linking tail swishing to potential diarrhea issues.
Determine the score for each of the three areas (flank, lower hind leg, udder) based on the amount of dirt (using palm and forearm as reference). (SUBTASKs for scoring)
After scoring, identify if the score suggests a problem (score of 2 anywhere). (SUBTASK)
If the lower hind legs are dirty (score 1 or 2), determine if the issue is with passageways or drainage. (SUBTASK)
If udder and lower parts are dirty (score 2), assess lying area for issues. (SUBTASK)
If tail and flank areas are dirty (score 2), check for signs of diarrhea or review diet. (SUBTASK)
For overall dirtiness (all over, score 2), check for overcrowding or manure removal problems. (SUBTASK)
Recognize that mastitis is an udder infection caused by bacteria entering through the teat canal. (SUBTASK)
Understand that dirty udders (high hygiene score) are associated with higher risk of mastitis. (SUBTASK)

tasks.task: Diagnosing shed hygiene issues based on dirt scores.
subtasks: Assessing cleaning of passageways or drainage where cows walk (lower hind legs dirty, score 1).
Checking lying area hygiene (udders and lower parts dirty, score 2).
Investigating tail and flank dirt (possible diarrhea or diet-related issue, score 2).
Evaluating overall dirtiness (all over, score 2) to check for overcrowding or manure removal issues.

tasks.task: Understanding mastitis infection process in dairy cows.
subtasks: Recognizing mastitis as an udder infection.
Identifying bacteria entry via teat canal.
Noting the correlation between dirty udders (high hygiene score) and higher risk of mastitis.
** For each cow, assess the **flank (including the tail)** area, determining if it is clean (0), has more than a palm-sized amount of dirt (1), or more than an forearm-length of dirt (2).
** Repeat the assessment for the **lower hind leg** area, following the same criteria.
** Evaluate the **udder** area using the same scoring system.

tasks.task: Interpreting the Scores to Identify Issues**
subtasks: ** If the lower hind legs score **1**, attribute the problem to potential passageway or drainage issues.
** If the udder and lower parts score **2**, suspect problems with the lying area.
** For **2** in the tail and flank area, consider signs of diarrhea or dietary issues.
** A **2** score across all areas indicates overcrowding or insufficient manure removal.
** Recognize **mastitis** as an infection of the udder.
** Understand bacteria enter through the teat canal.
** Connect higher hygiene scores (dirtier udders) to an increased risk of mastitis.
** Note **tail swishing** as a potential indicator of diarrhea, prompting a review of diet or health.
